Award.AwardTitle: AIR: PTTP: Si nanoelectronic FemtoSensor as ultrasensitive, label-free, protein based molecular diagnostic platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal aims to translate a unique Si nanoelectronic biosensor technology well developed at the University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) towards commercial products through a strong academia-industry partnership. The proposed work will develop a prototype instrument called FemtoSensor (femtoMolar sensitivity) Application Development Kit (ADK) based on a nanoscale Si on insulator (SOI) field effect transistor (FET) and to establish proof-of-concept protein-based tests towards a portable and low-cost diagnostic platform capable of label-free, rapid and early diagnostics of various diseases. The novel design of multiple Si nanochannel architecture brings critical advantages over previous bio-FETs, e.g. simultaneously achieving high sensitivity (femtoMolar), selectivity, and stability, as demonstrated by repeated tests in serum and tumor-cell lysate sample without pre-purification.

The full exploitation of the multi-nanochannel bio-FETs will contribute novel knowledge to the field of biosensor. The parametric evaluation of the sensor will address major unknowns of biosensing mechanism where strong electric field is applied, which is highly transformative to many types of sensors using electrokinetics. The proposed study will establish a numerical model of the performance curves to possibly predict sensing results, estimate correlation errors, and eliminate the need for sensor calibrations. If successful, the FemtoSensor ASK instruments with much better figure of merits than ELISA ($240M market size/year) would enable many researchers in university, research institutes, pharma, hospitals/clinics, diagnostics companies, government/defense facilities, to develop many new assays for diseases. The proposed activity will advance discovery and understanding of bio-FETs, while also promoting academic and industrial learning and training experiences. Inclusion of MBA students for entrepreneurship will complement the science and engineering student team members and give a more rich opportunity for learning and practicing innovation. Existing outreach programs from the PI's NSF CAREER award will be leveraged for this project.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This AIR program aims to translate a unique Si nanoelectronic biosensor technology developed at The University of Texas at Dallas (UTD) towards commercial products through academia-industry partnership. We have developed an all-electronic semiconductor nano-biosensors and a prototype instrument for various biosensing applications. Compared to conventional optical based sensing platforms, this type of semiconductor electronic biosensor provides the advantages of ultra-portability, system miniaturation, low cost,  high manufacturability, and considerable high performance. We have successfuly fabricated the sensor chip in batch process and chip-in-strip packaging in our university cleanroom. And then, we transferred the sensor design to industrial CMOS processes for manufacturability tests. We have collaborated with Diagtronix Inc. and built a semi-automatic table-top reader system for large sample amounts and a portable reader to connect with cell phones. We have also developed processes to optimize the surface chemistry which is necessary to make sensor more reliable. Systematic tests of pH, protein, and DNA have been performed, including the use of patient saliva and cell lysis samples. The nanosensor has shown the capability of rapid detection and high sensitivity. The stability of the sensor has been greatly improved using our hydrolysis process to achieve very low signal drifting over hours of test time, which is critical for commercial use. We obtained valuable knowledge of nanobiosensing. The CMOS nanosensor chip and the reader systems are making their way to beyond laboratory towards commercialization for applications in water and food safety tests, and possilby in long term for disease diagnostics.

The project has generated significant broader impacts. We have published 5 journal papers, 9 conference papers, and research results were reported in several leading conferences in nanotechnology. During the project, we have supported 8 graduate students, 1 post-doc, 4 undergraduate students, and 6 high school students (summer research). Two patents were filed and licensed to a startup company.

 


Last Modified: 09/04/2015
Modified by: Walter Hu
